Himmelsbach | Scuffle to have value for Cards

Louisville basketball proves it can win without star Montrezl Harrell

Himmelsbach | Scuffle to have value for Cards

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 7:50 p.m. EST December 20, 2014

Western Kentucky coach Ray Harper on 76-67 loss to Louisville

A fight broke out during an NCAA college basketball game between Louisville and Western Kentucky, Saturday, Dec. 20, 2014, in Bowling Green, Ky. (AP Photo/The Daily News, Miranda Pederson)(Photo: AP)

CONNECT 7 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — Louisville forward Montrezl Harrell, one of the best players in college basketball, watched the second half of his team's game against Western Kentucky on a silver 25-inch Toshiba television in the visitor's locker room.

He'd gone there Saturday after being ejected for throwing a forearm into the chest of the Hilltoppers' Avery Patterson during a skirmish with 38 seconds left in the first half. And suddenly, a road game in a raucous atmosphere had become even more daunting.

The Cardinals would have to find a way to win without their leader, their guide, their constant. In the locker room at halftime, Harrell had a quick and important message for his teammates.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville's Montrezl Harrell ejected from WKU game after scuffle

"I made a wrong choice," he recalled telling them. "I made a bad decision and I've got to live with the consequences, but you guys go out and win this game. I'm gonna be here in the locker room rooting you guys on, and you just have to pull it out."

About an hour later, after the Cardinals had rallied for their leader and pushed through a 76-67 win, Harrell was standing in the doorway to meet them. He was clapping. He was happy.

For the Cardinals, this game figured to be a good challenge before the schedule really becomes unforgiving. Along the way, though, it turned into something more.

It helped a player like Terry Rozier realize he can step into a leadership role and put this team on his back for long stretches. It helped a player like freshman Anas Mahmoud realize he can have an impact. And it helped all of the Cardinals realize that while afternoons are clearly better with Harrell, they do not have to unravel without him.

Later this season, U of L will look back on this game as one that helped it grow. This game will hold great value.

RELATED | U of L 76, WKU 67: What we learned

RELATED | Missed free throws doom WKU

"This was a life lesson for us," said Rozier, who poured in 32 points. "It was a test for us. Good thing we passed it."

I'd be stunned if Harrell is ejected from another game this season. Afterward, he showed remorse for his actions, and it was clear he was troubled by his inability to keep his cool.

But foul trouble happens and injuries happen and you just never know if or when the Cardinals might have to win a game without their superstar. Now they know that they can.

"Basketball is a game of adverse situations, and that was an adverse situation that we had to overcome," said U of L assistant Kenny Johnson, who spoke for coach Rick Pitino after the game. "Hopefully it prepares us for a situation later in the year, foul trouble or God forbid someone turns an ankle or whatever else. We learned how to play and rally through any type of adversity."

We already knew that Rozier is an elite player, but Mahmoud's emergence could be the most important development from this game. With Harrell out, WKU made a clear effort to attack more aggressively inside.

But Mahmoud did not back down, and he did not sit down. He played 19 minutes in the second half and finished with six points, five rebounds and three blocks. Those numbers aren't especially jarring, but he challenged Hilltoppers at the rim and even soared through the lane for a pair of aggressive dunks. He took a big step. He also deserves credit for grabbing Harrell and pulling him away from the scrum before the situation escalated.

Yes, it was unfortunate to see the Cardinals get into this harrowing and Harrell-less situation, but moving forward, this game will have benefits.

"I think it's gonna help us a lot," Harrell said. "It goes to show that even through the worst of adversity, the guys can still come out and get a win without me being on the floor. And I felt like that's something we really needed."

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach
